Award.AwardTitle: Understanding Molecular Driving Forces to Tailor Macromolecular Materials with Dual-Thermoresponsive Behavior

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1703402
PI: Jayaraman, Arthi
Institution: University of Delaware

Thermoresponsive molecules find important applications in sensors, electronics, actuators, drug delivery devices, and matrices for tissue engineering. Synthetic thermoresponsive polymers, such as poly(N-isopropyl acrylamide (PNIPAAM)), and biological thermoresponsive macromolecules, such as elastin-like polypeptides (ELPs), have been extensively studied. Various molecular-level design aspects of these thermoresponsive polymers, e.g., molecular composition, sequence, molecular weights, concentration, etc., provide ways to tune the phase transition (e.g. lower critical solution temperature or LCST) underlying their thermoresponsive behavior. Furthermore, conjugation of these thermoresponsive polymers to other polymers or substrates not only alters their LCST phase transition in a non-trivial manner but also facilitates ways to manipulate assembly and disassembly of nanostructures, by virtue of the dual thermal transitions associated with the two polymers. As of yet, however, there lacks a set of universal guidelines to predict how the molecular design of these polymers and their conjugates affect molecular-level interactions or physicochemical properties driving the thermodynamic phase transitions. The overarching goal of the proposed research is to capture the molecular interactions governing LCST transitions in an important class of thermoresponsive polymers, and to use the fundamental understanding to design thermoresponsive conjugates with two separately tunable thermal transitions.

The project will employ ELPs as the model system owing to the finely tuned control of hydrophobicity and molecular weight (and consequently transition temperatures) that is possible with these molecules versus other thermoresponsive materials. A key innovation is the introduction of associating peptide domains to the ELPs (ELP-CXPs) so that pre-association of short ELPs (that are computationally tractable) in the ELP-CXP drives the ELP LCST-like transition into an experimentally accessible temperature range. The collapse of the thermoresponsive ELP block subsequently drives phase separation of the pre-associated ELP-CXPs in aqueous solution. The resulting structures will also undergo an additional disassembly transition at even higher temperatures owing to the unfolding of the associating block (CXP). Both the lengths and compositions of the CXP and ELP blocks can be altered to yield tailored transitions and assembly/disassembly; specific design features will be informed by the development of the computational methods. The modular design and precise composition of the ELP-CXP conjugates offers strategies not only to modulate the transition temperature of the ELP domain via unreported methods, but also to manipulate assembly and disassembly of nanostructures, which has multiple applications in nanocomposites, nanoscale templating, and drug delivery. Importantly, owing to the presence of the CXP domain, these materials will be competent for further elaboration with peptide-modified molecules and nanoparticles, expanding the versatility of the conjugates in nanotechnology applications. The interdisciplinary nature of the research will enrich the training of graduate and undergraduate students. Outreach activities are proposed aimed at recruitment and retention of female and underrepresented minority researchers in science and engineering careers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this NSF-funded project,  Jayaraman (PI), Kiick (co-PI) and their teams at University of Delaware used molecular simulations and experiments in a synergistic manner to link the molecular design of elastin-like peptides (ELPs) and conjugates of ELPs to collagen-like peptides (CLPs) to their physicochemical properties and their thermo-responsive behavior. This led to the understanding of the molecular underpinnings of the inverse temperature phase transition in ELPs and ELPs when conjugated to CLP in aqueous solutions; this phenomenon is where ELP molecules are stable in water at low temperatures and phase separate upon increasing temperature. CLPs triple helical structures also undergo structural transition with increasing temperature; this is called a melting transition where the triple helix dissociates into three individual CLP strands. By conjugation of CLPs to ELPs this team encoded dual thermo-responsive transitions into ELP-CLP conjugates - the inverse temperature transition of the ELP and melting transition of the CLP. This dual temperature responsiveness has been used to drive the assembly and the disassembly of ELP-CLP conjugates into nanostructures (e.g., vesicles, nanoplatelets) that are being used for a variety of applications including drug delivery.

Intellectual Merit: Using  experiments an simulations with newly developed models this team elucidated how conjugation of ELP and CLP shifts the inverse transition temperature (Tt) of ELP to lower values, and how the design of ELP (e.g., length, composition, sequence) tuned this Tt. They   controlled the morphologies of ELP-CLP assembled structures, proving the feasibility of achieving multistep assembly imparted by two thermally responsive molecular domains to form unique nanostructures that can be used in delivery applications. The entire project led to several design rules listed next:

1.: Increasing crowding of ELP chains by conjugating to a substrate (CLP or another macromolecule) is a facile way to shift Tt values of short ELP molecules (which do not exhibit LCST-like transition in unconjugated form) to sufficiently low temperatures to be accessible under common experimental conditions.

2: Increasing the ELP guest residue [i.e., X in (VPGXG)n sequence] hydrophobicity, local chain stiffness, and propensity to form turn structures lowers ELP?s Tt.

3: Increasing the number of F to Y replacements in ELP-CLP conjugates generally reduces the Tt, and the placement of Y close to the CLP tethering point increases Tt.

4: Variations in the domain lengths of W/F-containing ELP-CLP conjugates are shown experimentally to provide a sensitive means to tune morphology and vesicle size

Broader Impacts.

 Training & Mentoring: 4 graduate students - Joshua Condon, Phillip Taylor (URM), Jingya Qin (URM) and Haofu Huang - and 1 postdoc - Prhashanna Ammu-, with partial support from this grant, were trained in an inter-disciplinary manner.

Pedagogy: Jayaraman developed  a new elective CHEG 667/867 Molecular modeling and simulation of soft materials in Spring 2019. To extend the pedagogy beyond the classroom, Jayaraman was invited to write a perspective on Modeling and Simulation of Polymers: A Roadmap in Macromolecules.9 This perspective is ranked as the most read article of Macromolecules in 2020. She was also invited to write a review article on Modeling and simulations of peptide-polymer conjugates to be published in the Annual Review of Chemical and Biomolecular Engineering in 20205; she took this opportunity to train her graduate student Phillip Taylor on such review writing. 

University-industry-national lab partnerships: Administrative activities by Kiick led to scientific development of partnerships with select US DOE National Laboratories. Over 50 faculty members at UD have been involved in project partnership discussions, with at least five projects developed and advanced through these efforts. 

Editorial activities: Kiick serves on the editorial advisory board of RSC Journal: Molecular Systems Design and Engineering (MSDE). Jayaraman recently co-edited a special MSDE themed issue of 10 articles on Molecular design of biomimetic, bioinspired and biorelevant materials. Jayaraman also serves as an Associate Editor for Macromolecules and as Deputy Editor for ACS Polymers Au the new fully open access journal for polymer science.  

Diversity & Inclusion: Kiick has guided faculty hiring practices in the College of Engineering, in which best practices in recruiting, mentoring, and retaining faculty were presented to all faculty members serving on search committees who were then required to demonstrate their deliberate actions to generate as diverse an applicant pool as possible. Kiick also participated in regional science outreach days in the mid-Atlantic aiimed at inclusion of URM groups in the new MSEG undergraduate minor. Jayaraman wrote an article in the AIChE Computational Molecular Science and Engineering Forum (COMSEF) newsletter on A broader view: Creating an inclusive academic and work environment through our classroom and research lab interactions to encourage actions from PIs to improve inclusion within academic environment.
